metadata.product: TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Hi Victoria, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Sarah, and I’m a representative from TIJN. We really appreciate you sharing your feedback with us through your online review, and we wanted to follow up directly to understand your experience even better. Is this still a good time for you?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Hi Sarah, yes, absolutely. Thank you for reaching out. I’m happy to chat.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Wonderful. To start, could you just quickly confirm that you purchased our TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses, the square nerd eyeglasses frame, a few months ago?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** That’s right, yes. The matte black ones. I think I got them maybe, oh gosh, I want to say about four months ago now? Give or take a week or two.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Perfect. And just to confirm, you’re currently working as a therapist, correct?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Yes, that’s right. I specialize in family therapy, and I do a mix of in-person and a good amount of tele-health sessions, plus all the administrative stuff and notes, of course.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Got it, thank you for clarifying. Your review mentioned a significant amount of screen time impacting your eyes. Could you tell me a little more about what your daily screen usage looks like in your role as a therapist? What kinds of tasks are you typically doing on screens?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. Well, beyond the actual virtual sessions, which can be anywhere from two to five hours a day depending on my schedule, there’s just so much documentation. You know, writing up notes after each session, preparing for future sessions, doing research for specific client needs, updating client files, and then all the general emails and communication. And honestly, sometimes in the evenings, I’m just trying to decompress by watching a show or something, so it adds up to a *lot* of hours. Before these glasses, it was just constant strain, like a gritty feeling, and those awful migraines.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That sounds incredibly demanding. You mentioned you were "desperate for relief." What had you tried before you decided to purchase blue light blocking glasses?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Hmm, good question. Before these, I tried to be more mindful of taking breaks, doing the 20-20-20 rule, you know, looking away every 20 minutes. I tried eye drops for the dryness, which helped a little, but it was just a temporary fix. I even adjusted my monitor settings, tried different lighting in my office. But nothing really seemed to cut through the underlying fatigue and the feeling that my eyes were just constantly overworked. The migraines were the worst, though. Those really disrupted my ability to work or even just live normally.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** It sounds like you exhausted quite a few conventional solutions. When you were looking for blue light glasses, what specifically drew you to the TIJN square frames compared to other options you might have seen online?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Well, a few things. First, the style. I wanted something that looked professional enough for my virtual sessions. I mean, my clients see me through the screen, and I don't want to look like I just rolled out of bed, you know? The square frames with the matte black finish really caught my eye – they looked chic and kind of intelligent without being overly flashy. I also really liked that "subtly nerdy" vibe I mentioned in the review. And honestly, the price point was a huge factor. As a therapist, especially early in my private practice, every dollar counts, and these were incredibly budget-friendly compared to some of the other brands I saw that were two, three, even four times the price.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. Aesthetics and affordability are definitely key considerations for many. You mentioned the packaging was "modest" but your initial assessment of the frames themselves was positive. Could you elaborate a bit on your first impressions when you took them out of the soft pouch?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Sure. The packaging itself was just… a pouch and a cloth. No big fancy box, which is fine, but it was noticeable. When I took the glasses out though, I was really pleasantly surprised. They *do* look more expensive than they are. The matte black finish is smooth, and the lines are really clean. They felt very light, which was good because I was worried about them feeling heavy on my nose after a long day. And the hinges seemed… solid enough. Not super high-end, obviously, but not flimsy to the point where I thought they’d break right away. I put them on, and immediately thought, "Okay, these look good."

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s great to hear. Now, shifting to the user experience, you immediately noticed the yellow tint. You described it as a "mild, warm hue." Can you walk me through your adjustment period? Did it take long to get used to?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. It was definitely noticeable right away. My white screen suddenly looked creamy, like an old newspaper or something. My initial thought was, "Oh, this is going to be annoying." But honestly, I adjusted to it surprisingly quickly. Within a day, maybe two, it just became the new normal for my screen. My brain just filtered it out, I guess. In fact, after that initial phase, I started to really appreciate it. It made the screen feel… softer. Less harsh, definitely. My eyes just didn't have to work as hard against that bright blue-white.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's really interesting how quickly you adapted. You did mention, however, that the tint became an issue for "any task involving visual materials where precise color is crucial." Could you give me some specific examples of those kinds of tasks in your profession where you felt the need to take the glasses off?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Hmm, yeah. So for most of my note-taking and reading, it’s totally fine. But sometimes, when I'm reviewing research, there might be infographics or charts with specific color coding that I need to interpret accurately. Or, some clients might share creative work with me – like artwork or digital projects – as part of their therapeutic process, and for those, I really want to see the true colors, you know? Even just something simple like trying to pick out an outfit online for myself, or if I'm looking at, um, something for my home. Those are the times I find myself instinctively reaching up to take them off for a moment. It’s not constant, but it *does* happen.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I understand. It sounds like those are specific, intermittent needs rather than a pervasive problem during your core work. On the flip side, you highlighted the "most significant benefit" as the noticeable reduction in eye strain and headaches. Could you quantify that for me, if possible? For example, how frequently were you experiencing migraines before, and how has that changed since using the glasses?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Oh, wow, that’s a great question. Before, it was… crippling. Seriously. I was getting migraines probably once every two to three weeks, sometimes even more frequently if I had a particularly heavy screen-time week. And when they hit, they were debilitating. I’d lose a whole day, sometimes two. Since wearing these glasses, I can honestly say I've only had maybe one, *maybe* two, really significant migraines in the past four months. And even those felt less intense, almost like they were trying to start but didn't quite get there. The constant eye strain and gritty feeling? That's almost completely gone. It’s like night and day.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s incredibly impactful feedback, Victoria. It really speaks to the core function of the product. You also mentioned feeling that the reduced blue light exposure helps you transition to sleep more easily. Can you expand on that a bit?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Yeah, I think so. I wouldn't say I just put them on and BAM, I'm asleep. That's not it. But I do wear them in the evenings if I'm still on my laptop or even just scrolling on my phone a bit. What I've noticed is that my eyes just feel generally calmer, less "wired" or stimulated. It’s easier to just put the screen away and feel like my brain can start winding down. It’s a more gentle transition, I guess. Before, it felt like my eyes were still buzzing from the screen, making it harder to relax. Now, I feel that sense of calm and less visual stimulation, which definitely helps with the overall unwinding process.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That subtle but significant shift sounds very beneficial for your overall well-being. And in terms of comfort, you described them as excellent, wearing them for hours without pressure points. Are there any particular features about the fit or design that contribute to that comfort?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Definitely their weight. Or rather, lack of it. They are so lightweight. I've had glasses before, even just sunglasses, that start to pinch behind my ears or leave marks on my nose after a while. With these, I genuinely forget I'm wearing them. I wear them for six, seven, eight hours straight sometimes during my workday, and I never feel that pressure. They just kind of... disappear on my face. And they fit well, too. They don't slide down my nose or feel loose. They just stay put.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's high praise for long-term wear. Now, you rated us a 4 out of 5 stars, and you mentioned the slight tint and the lightweight plastic's durability as reasons for not giving a full five. Could you tell me if you've experienced any specific durability issues or if that's more of a general concern given the material?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** It’s more of a general concern, honestly. I haven't had them break or anything. But because they're so light, they just *feel* like if I dropped them on a hard floor, or if they got sat on, they'd probably be done for. I'm pretty careful with them, so it hasn’t been an issue yet. But I know for a fact that a more expensive, sturdier pair would probably withstand more accidental abuse. It’s just the trade-off, right? For the price, I can't really complain, but it’s definitely something I'm conscious of. And the extremely subtle internal reflection I mentioned? I still notice it sometimes, but it's truly so minor, it barely warrants mentioning. It's just there *sometimes* if the light hits it just right.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Understood. So, it's more about perceived robustness than actual failure you've experienced. Given your experience, if you were to imagine the "perfect" blue light blocking glasses for someone in your profession, what features would they have? What would make these a five-star product for you?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Oh, that's a fun thought. Okay, so obviously keeping the effectiveness of the blue light blocking – that's non-negotiable. The style is great too, I wouldn't change that. But for me, the ideal would be… glasses with that amazing comfort and effectiveness, but with little to no visible tint. Or maybe, hear me out, a technology that could dynamically adjust the tint depending on what you're looking at? That's probably super futuristic, but if I'm dreaming! [laughs] Failing that, just a really, truly clear lens that still blocks blue light. And then, a slightly more robust frame material, but without adding significant weight or bumping the price point too high. That's a tall order, I know, but that would be perfect.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** [laughs] No, that’s exactly the kind of forward-thinking feedback we appreciate, Victoria. It helps us understand where the technology could go. Following up on that, is there anything that would make you consider switching to a competitor's product right now?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Hmm, right now? Probably not, honestly. These have been such a game-changer for my eye strain and migraines, and the price was so good. I’m pretty happy. What *would* make me switch, though, would be if another brand offered a similar level of effectiveness and comfort, but with significantly less or no tint, and *still* managed to keep it in a similar affordable price range. Or, if these ones suddenly became wildly expensive. But as they are now, for the value, they’re pretty hard to beat. I'm not actively looking to switch, let's put it that way.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s fantastic to hear. You also said in your review that you would "highly recommend" these. Who specifically do you think would benefit most from these glasses?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Anyone who spends a lot of time on screens, really. But especially people in professions similar to mine, or teachers, or students, anyone who has long hours in front of a computer. If you’re getting that constant eye fatigue, dry eyes, or screen-induced headaches, and you’re on a budget, these are a no-brainer. I've actually told a few of my colleagues about them already. I mean, for the price, it’s such a low-risk way to try and get some genuine relief.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s a very clear endorsement, Victoria. Just one final question for me today. Based on your entire experience with the TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses, from the purchase to using them daily, on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is "extremely dissatisfied" and 10 is "extremely satisfied," what would be your overall satisfaction rating?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** Oh, that’s easy. I’d give them a strong 8.5, maybe even a 9. They’ve genuinely made a huge difference in my daily comfort and well-being. The tint is the only thing holding it back from a perfect 10, but even that is pretty minor for most of my work. They really deliver on their promise.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Thank you so much, Victoria. That’s incredibly valuable feedback for us, and we truly appreciate your honesty and time today. Your insights are going to be very helpful as we continue to improve our products. Is there anything else you’d like to add or any other questions for me?

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** No, I think we covered everything. Thanks for listening! It’s nice to know companies actually pay attention to reviews.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** We certainly do! Thank you again, Victoria. Enjoy the rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Victoria
transcript.text: ** You too, Sarah. Bye!
